title: Leon Gawenda
text:
I am a PhD student at the Faculty of Sociology at Bielefeld University (Working Group Quantitative Methods). I work at the SOEP RegioHub, a project funded by the Leibniz Foundation, the German Institute for Economic Research (DIW) and Bielefeld University.
In my research, I study geographical patterns of political participation and their history. More generally, I am a sociologist and political scientist interested in political participation, party politcs and environmental sociology. I predominantly work with electoral and survey data using quantitative methods.

title: Leon Gawenda
text:
Current projects
Working Paper: Continuity in Germany’s electoral Geography since the German Empire

I assess the degree of continuity in spatial patterns of voting across 130 years. I conduct a spatial analysis by combining historical and contemporary census and electoral data through spatial interpolation. Based on cleavage theory, I can show how traditional parties still benefit from spatial continuities in the distribution of ‘cleavage groups’. Continuity in the electoral geography have been sustained by a religious geography that has remained fairly stable.
